posts.name: Chris LaSalle
posts.cooked:
I am wondering if it is advisable to utilize Blue Loctite to secure the electrical wiring to the motor control head on the Kraken Motor? My feeling is that Loctite has some properties that would inhibit a really good electrical connection to the motor.

We purchased the tools from CTRE to put the specified torque to the connections.

Is this good enough to ensure connections will stay put on the motor?

We will be using the WCP adapter boards.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
This question has been asked and the historical answers has been ‚Äúno‚Äù do not use loctite of any variety on the electrical connections of the Kraken.

I am not up to date on reading the kraken docs however, so follow official install instructions for the most up to date information.

I have not heard of teams having trouble with wiring connections coming loose this first year of kraken use.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
I think the official instruction suggest apply correct torque on both screw terminal.

Location Screw Size Driver Size Torque Value Power Terminals #6-32 x 1/4" IP10 or T10 0.9 N*m CAN Terminals #4-40 x 1/4" IP8 or T8 0.6 N*m

CTRE also have a special screw driver (Torque Wrench) for you to do this.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: And, if you want to turn it up to 11, Nordlock makes the right size washers

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: Please use the proper torque specs for the screws, and the proper lengths. Do not use other items like thread locker, lock washers, etc. When properly seated, and torqued, the ring terminals are solid.

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked: Thread locker and electricity don‚Äôt mix.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: This thread seems as good as any for this question: Are there any official resources for the best/most cost effective ring terminals and crimper for both can and 10/12AWG power wires? I could almost certainly just find a suitable solution on McMaster but the cost (especially for the crimper) would be hard to justify.

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked:
Full Disclosure: I work at CTR Electronics.

Wiring - Page 1 - CTR Electronics has a lot of what you are looking for. We offer a crimp tool , heat shrink , 10 awg wire , ring terminals for 10 and 22 awg wire , and CAN bus cable , all of which is useful for wiring up a Kraken motor, if you want to create your own wiring.

link_counts.title: Non-insulated Terminal Crimp Tool by IWISS

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: Hi Jon, thanks for the summary. It might be beneficial to direct people to these from the Kraken store page and manual, though I see that searching ‚ÄúKraken‚Äù on the website returns most of these product pages as well.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: Jon, another question I just thought of. You suggest non-insulated ring terminals. Are insulated ring terminals not recommended? I already have No.6 10AWG insulated terminals in stock and have the appropriate tool for them.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
There is a terminal area cover that protects the terminals from falling debris (think dropping a screw or screwdriver and it shorts power + and -). The clearance between this terminal cover and terminals is tight, and with ridged nylon, PVC or other rigid insulating material you are likely to run into interference trouble installing the terminal cover on the back of the motor.

If your insulated ring terminals are of the heat shrink variety, you may not run into issues.

Likewise you can try the terminals you have or even pull off the rigid insulating material before crimping to make it into an uninsulated terminal.

posts.name: cbix2
posts.cooked:
John, I have seen the Talon FX PowerPole Adapter Board by West Coast Products.  This seems convenient, but I am wondering if it makes more sense to just use the ring terminals on the Kraken for both the power and the CAN wires.  Quick connects are usually quicker, but a bit less secure.  I am also not a fan of the CAN wire connections coming out of the end of the Kraken motor, which, on the SDS MK4i, faces down, so running over a game piece could easily dislodge some of the CAN wires.  The power wires are more protected.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
we had a kraken-ring-terminal failure this week, so i‚Äôm looking for ways to avoid that.

100% of the other fasteners on the robot will rattle loose without some sort of ‚Äúother item‚Äù to secure them ‚Ä¶

so are nordlocks really a bad idea?

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
What did the wire management look like coming off the failed terminal?

With proper torque and the wires managed to not let ring terminals torque on the screws we haven‚Äôt had any wiring failures after we started using a good torque wrench.

CTRE is nervous about approving lockwashers because that will mess with your depth of engagement on the screw and potentially cause more trouble than it solves. Especially a bad lockwasher design like a springlock.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the failure was really just looseness.  it was an interesting failure, the control electronics never hiccuped but the power electronics couldn‚Äôt get any current.  it squealed like it was hitting a current limit, and it was easy to turn by hand.  anyway the wire management seemed fine to me, there was strain relief within, say, two inches.

are wave washers any good?  they‚Äôre pretty thin.

cbix2:

I am also not a fan of the CAN wire connections coming out of the end of the Kraken motor, which, on the SDS MK4i, faces down, so running over a game piece could easily dislodge some of the CAN wires. The power wires are more protected.

This is a concern for me as well. I LOVE being able to power the cancoder from the motor and saving on some wiring. But I‚Äôm worried about protecting those connections. If we didn‚Äôt have inverted motors it wouldn‚Äôt be an issues.

posts.name: Zach Kerfoot
posts.cooked:
We had this exact nightmare happen during Match 10 of Greater KC this year. A part fell off of a robot, hitting the cancoder and CAN connectors on one of our Kraken motors on our inverted motors, killed our swerve for the rest of the match. Not a fun time scrambling to replace the board and recrimp the Molex connector in the pit right before another match. Shortly after the regional we removed the adapter boards and hardwired every motor on the drive with ring terminals. IMG_3944 1331√ó1831 363 KB

IMG_3944 1331√ó1831 363 KB

IMG_3944 1331√ó1831 363 KB
ANDDDD you‚Äôve convinced me to stay with the terminals. At least for swerve.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

With proper torque and the wires managed to not let ring terminals torque on the screws

This really it - those are small fasteners but they need to be properly torqued just like the head bolts on some big diesel engine.

I consider the pre-set torque tools from CTR to be expensive, but worth it.  Those are fasteners that you need to keep tight but not overtighten them (the cost over overtightening them be more than I, and many others, could bear).

And there is no way to say too much about properly strain relieving the wires to keep them clear and NOT apply any torque as @s-neff mentioned; that is key to keep them tight as well.
